item.title: Magit Forge on macOS
item.description:
I’ve tried many editor git integrations over the years, in Vim, VS Code, Intellij, Sublime, as well as various git GUIs. However I’ve never found something nearly as powerful and efficient day to day as working on the command line.

While I will probably never give up the command line, with Emacs’ Magit I’ve finally found a valuable companion which feels as powerful and efficient as the cli interface. The magit status window is a super powerful base point for most git operations. And with Magit Forge you can make it even more powerful.

item.title: beorg - org mode on the go
item.description:
One of the big reasons I finally succumbed to the Evil side was the search for a comprehensive notes and todo system.

I’ve been testing many approaches, like Task Warrior and Workflowy, but org-mode is by far the best I’ve found so far.

In 2020 mobile is a critical component for such a system, and thus beorg was an important part of that decision. It’s an impressive piece of software, implementing all the important features of org mode like syncing, all aspects of scheduling and repeats , custom todo states and a comprehensive parser.

item.title: Visual Fill Column Mode
item.description:
When writing text content, soft wrap is preferable to breaking lines. However, with Emacs soft wrap defaults to the line of your window, which could be quite long. This ELPA module allows you to configure the line length to your preference.
